catalog_info.title: Global Reproductive Health
catalog_info.description: This interdisciplinary seminar examines how gender, poverty, development and global health policies, legacies of colonialism, and social institutions influence sexual and reproductive health outcomes (pregnancy, maternal health, HIV/AIDS, cervical cancer, sexual violence) and access to sexual and reproductive health services (family planning, abortion, HIV testing and counseling, cervical cancer screening) among women in low-income countries. We will address how social and economic context affect women's sexual and reproductive health across countries in the Global South and examine how inequities based on socioeconomic position, ethnicity, nationality, religion, gender, and sexuality shape women's sexual and reproductive health inequities within these countries. Further, we will discuss how community-based health interventions that target the social determinants of health at multiple levels can help promote the sexual and reproductive health and rights of women in low-income countries.
